24988628.trustfund:
TF097187-GPOBA (W3 Sup) Yemen Queen
            Sheba Safe Motherhood,TF092181-GPOBA W3-YEMEN HEALTH - QUEEN
            OF SHEBA SAFE MOTHERHOOD PROJECT
24988628.majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Safe Motherhood Voucher Program for
            Yemen received a moderately satisfactory outcome rating with
            high risk to development outcome. Both the Bank and the
            Borrower received moderately satisfactory performance
            ratings. Two restructurings took placing during this
            project. The first restructuring includes a revised price
            list for the defined safe motherhood services estimated that
            the allocated grant for service provision would be able to
            cover the subsidies for only a fraction of beneficiaries;
            therefore the restructuring reduced the number of target
            beneficiaries to reflect the revised cost structure. The
            second restructuring involved a withdrawal of Saudi General
            Hospital (SGH), the second service provider, and revised
            estimations of the time that would be required to reach the
            revised end-target. The restructuring changes were: (i)
            amendment of the revised PDO with an amended key project
            indicator of 15,000 beneficiaries based on a single service
            provider; (ii) extension of the project closing date by
            eighteen months to meet the revised target of 15,000; (iii)
            reallocation of Grant proceeds; and (iv) a cancellation of
            unused grant funds because of withdrawal of SGH. The PDO was
            revised twice and reflects the following: (a) provide
            quality maternal care to about 30,000 eligible women in
            targeted districts in Sana'a; and (b) design and
            implement a model of maternal care which demonstrates how
            Yemeni public policy on maternal and child care can be
            effectively integrated with private health provision. There
            were several lessons learned from this project and include
            the following: (1) A better clarity and realism on the
            applicability of GPOBA policies and procedures to Bank
            projects is critical. (2) While the project design was no
            doubt innovative for the Yemen health sector and benefitted
            from this pilot, with hindsight it could have benefited from
            a much more robust assessment of readiness of all parties,
            and, given the innovative project approach and fragile
            context, from more intensive collaboration amongst all
            parties during preparation and implementation. (3) When
            introducing innovations, which are no doubt needed to
            influence desired development outcomes, smaller pilots with
            regular reviews may be more effective. (4) There is no doubt
            that all projects require M&E; that robust M&E is a
            core concept for successful performance based projects; and,
            that independent verification is required because the
            payment of grant subsidies is based on achievement of
            individual outputs. There is an important distinction to be
            made between a robust system and a complex system. (5) A
            more structured and concerted engagement with Government,
            the Ministry of Health (required) and also the Ministry of
            Finance (desirable), is required for any project that wishes
            to effectively influence public policy, especially one that
            envisions growth using government and donor mobilized
            resources, as in this instance.

16414535.trustfund:
TF092181-GPOBA W3-YEMEN HEALTH - QUEEN
            OF SHEBA SAFE MOTHERHOOD PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen, Republic of - Queen of Sheba Safe
            Motherhood Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Queen of Sheba
            Safe Motherhood Project are to: (a) provide quality maternal
            care to about 30,000 eligible women in targeted districts in
            Sana'a; and (b) design and implement a model of
            maternal care which demonstrates how Yemeni public policy on
            maternal and child care can be effectively integrated with
            private health provision. The changes are: (i) extension of
            the project closing date; (ii) amendment of the revised
            project development objective (PDO); (iii) reallocation of
            grant proceeds; and (iv) cancellation of a portion of the
            unused grant funds.
